DOC.HEAD: Snow and Record Cold for Christmas in the Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Record lows were confined to the Southeast on Monday as a major cold wave dwindled, but more cool air began moving into northern Minnesota and heavy snow fell around Lake Superior. Monday's low of zero degrees at Wilmington, N.C., broke the city's previous all-time record of 5 above, which had stood since February 1899. The low of 33 degrees at Miami Beach, Fla., equalled that city's record for all of December, established just the day before. Other record lows Monday, all in Florida, were 29 at Fort Lauderdale, 46 at Key West, and 30 at Miami, the National Weather Service reported, a far cry from last week when temperatures hit record lows in more than 100 cities a day. A cold front nosed into the northern Plains region and the upper Mississippi Valley during the afternoon, kicking up snow and gusty wind that sharply reducing visibility in some areas. Squalls associated with the cold front produced heavy snow along the shoreline of Lake Superior, and up to 12 inches of new snow was possible by Tuesday in parts of western and central Upper Michigan near the lakeshore, the weather service said. A weak storm system brought light snow to the Tennessee Valley early Monday and snow flurries were reported as far south as the central Gulf Coast. Mobile, Ala., reported snow on Christmas for the first time since record-keeping began in 1871. Snow showers were scattered from Missouri and Tennessee to the Great Lakes and western New England. Freezing drizzle was reported in northern Illinois during the morning. Temperatures dropped below freezing early Monday across most of the nation, with sub-zero readings reported across New England and eastern New York state, and parts of West Virginia and coastal North Carolina. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 17 degrees below zero at Houlton, Maine. A warm front crossing the Great Lakes region, middle Mississippi Valley and southern Plains spread more seasonable temperatures eastward. Afternoon readings were in the 40s in the central Plains and in the 50s across the southern Plains.
